select_from.title: select_from
select_from.description: The SELECT statement is used to retrieve data from one or more tables. FROM specifies the table(s) to query.
select_from.additionalInfo: SELECT is the most common SQL command. It allows you to specify which columns you want to retrieve and from which tables.

where.title: where
where.description: The WHERE clause is used to filter records based on specific conditions.
where.additionalInfo: It allows you to specify criteria that returned rows must meet, effectively narrowing down your result set.

limit.title: limit
limit.description: The LIMIT clause is used to specify the maximum number of rows to return in the result set.
limit.additionalInfo: This is particularly useful for pagination or when you only need a subset of the results.

left_join.title: left_join
left_join.description: LEFT JOIN returns all records from the left table and matched records from the right table. If there's no match, NULL values are returned for right table columns.
left_join.additionalInfo: This is useful when you want to include all records from one table even if they don't have corresponding records in the joined table.

group_by.title: group_by
group_by.description: GROUP BY is used to group rows that have the same values in specified columns into summary rows.
group_by.additionalInfo: It's often used with aggregate functions like COUNT(), MAX(), MIN(), SUM(), AVG() to perform calculations on each group.

partition_by.title: partition_by
partition_by.description: PARTITION BY divides the result set into partitions and performs computations on each subset of partitioned data.
partition_by.additionalInfo: It's commonly used with window functions to perform calculations across a set of rows that are related to the current row.

order_by.title: order_by
order_by.description: ORDER BY is used to sort the result set in ascending or descending order based on one or more columns.
order_by.additionalInfo: You can specify ASC for ascending order (default) or DESC for descending order.

with.title: with
with.description: The WITH clause, also known as Common Table Expression (CTE), allows you to name a subquery and reference it later in the main query.
with.additionalInfo: It's useful for improving readability and allowing you to reference the same subquery multiple times in a single statement.

having.title: having
having.description: The HAVING clause is used to specify a search condition for a group or an aggregate. It's often used with GROUP BY.
having.additionalInfo: Unlike WHERE, which filters individual rows before grouping, HAVING filters groups after they've been created.

qualify.title: qualify
qualify.description: QUALIFY is used to filter the results of window functions. It's similar to WHERE, but operates on the results of window functions.
qualify.additionalInfo: This clause is specific to certain databases like Snowflake and is not part of standard SQL.
